text: in making my first trip as Secretary of
State to Asia I hope to signal that we
need strong partners across the Pacific
just as we need strong partners across
the Atlantic Secretary of State Clinton
delivered the first major speech of her
tenure as Secretary of State here in New
York at the asia society and it was also
a preview of her first trip which begins
on sunday she's going to four countries
in Asia Indonesia South Korea Japan and
China and this trip will in a way set
the tone for us Asian relations for the
next several years global solutions are
essential to addressing climate change
in the need for clean sources of energy
the point she made very strongly in the
speech today was one of partnership
particularly between the United States
and China and very much built around the
idea of climate change and what the
United States and China need to do
together as the world's two largest
emitters of carbon dioxide to try to
stem global warming now our nation has
been the largest historic emitter of
greenhouse gases and we acknowledge that
we must lead efforts to cut harmful
emissions and build a lower carbon
economy but each of the countries that
i'm visiting also have a role to play in
this effort i will press the case for
clean energy in both Japan and South
Korea and look for ways to work with
Indonesia as well the Secretary of State
didn't break any new ground on the
nuclear problem in North Korea she did
warn North Korea however that some of
its recent provocative statements toward
South Korea were a problem and she sort
of held out the promise that if North
Korea were to deliver on its pulling
back on its nuclear ambitions that it
might someday have a direct engagement
with the United States sciences while
developing deep she's trying to maintain
a positive tone and start on this trip
with a good atmosphere while most people
believe that human rights will be a
major part of the Secretary's agenda
she's not expected to bring it up in a
very confrontational or forceful way on
this first visit to
often in the recent past our government
has acted reflexively before considering
available facts and evidence or hearing
the perspectives of others but President
Obama and I are committed to a foreign
policy that is neither impulsive nor
ideological one that values what others
have to say and when we have differences
which we will we will discuss them
frankly and specify those which limit
our capacity to cooperate
